Setting this property to Y will prevent dead locking on YFS_Inventory_Item table during order creation and when sychronizing changes from a shipment back to the order. This parameter is only used if the order contains a logical kit, or when a shipment contains shipment lines from different orders. Setting this property to Y will result into holding lock on YFS_Inventory_Item table for longer period. So, this may degrade overall system performance. Because of this reason, you should set this property to Y only if you are getting excessive dead locks on YFS_Inventory_Item table.

Set the following property to 'Y' to process one serial at a time during receiving i.e on scanning one serial user is taken to Disposition Code entry screen.

releaseTaskAgent uses the below mentioned property to select the mode of execution for releasing tasks. 01: Location Driven. All the pending tasks from the location are evaluated. 02: Reference(eg. ShipmentNo) Driven. All the pending tasks for the reference are evaluated. The default value of this property is 01 (ie Location Driven).

In case of item driven packing, shipment level pack tasks are created in order to reserve the shipment against the packer. And, once the shipment packing is complete, these tasks are deleted from from DB. Due to some reason if packing for this shipment could not be completed by the packer, these idle pack tasks blocks other users from packing this shipment. This property can used to define maximum time, in minutes, for which the shipment level idle pack tasks are retained. If it is set to 120, and a user scans a Pallet in Pack HSDE, pack tasks created 120 minutes before will be deleted so that the unpacked blocked shipment becomes available to other users. The default value is taken as 60 minutes.

Based on this property, the maximum user constraints defined for a task type will be evaulated. If task is manually assigned to a user and this property is set to Y, the maximun user constraint defined for task type will not be honoured. To retain the existing behavior, set this property to N

Set this property to 'Y' to show the task details (Pick Location, Item ID and Quantity ) in RF mobile terminal when tasktype is defined to say pick onto equipment. Specifies the maximum size of the file that can be uploaded per installation, specified either in bytes (B), kilobytes (KB), megabytes (MB) or gigabytes (GB). The default value is 10 MB. To have no file size limit, the value should be -1. Use sc.file.upload.maxfilesize.<table_name> to specify the maximum size of the file that can be uploaded for a table whose name is <table_name>, for example, sc.file.upload.maxfilesize.YFS_USER=[something]. sc.file.upload.maxfilesize=10MB

Specifies the file types that can be uploaded per installation. To have no restrictions on the allowed file types, set the property to all. Note: if the defaulted values are removed, then an exception will be thrown during the file upload. Use the sc.file.upload.allowedfiletypes.<table_name> property to specify the file types that can be uploaded for the specified table. The <table_name> variable is the parent table name for which files are being attached. sc.file.upload.allowedfiletypes=*.csv
Specifies the number of days(from the date of creation of the Upload Jobs), after which the upload jobs are considered to be purged from the system. The default value is 5 Days.

This property is used to decide the logic that is used to determine the shards from where data needs to be obtained for get-list operations Allowed Values : 1. disabled - This disables obtaining data from other shards. 2. ssi - Uses the out of box 'Sterling Search Index' index to determine the shards to obtain data from. 3. nonindexed - To be used when sharding is used, but search index is not to be used to determine the shards to obtain data from. This ensures that data is obtained from ALL SHARDS. 4. <custom value> - Any custom implementation to be used to determine shards to obtain data from. Use the property 'api.colony.indexer.<custom value>.class' below to provide the name of the implementing class. Default Value : disabled
PropertyMetadata.PermissibleValues: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <Values> <Value Name="disabled"/> <Value Name="ssi"/> <Value Name="nonindexed"/> <Value Name="<a custom value>"/> </Values>

PropertyMetadata.Description: If '<custom value>' is chosen above, provide the fully qualified class name of the class implementing com.ibm.sterling.afc.colony.indexer.PLTIndexingService
This property indicates the class name which provides the OOB implementation for index search. This is not to be modified.

There are APIs enabled to search against multiple indices. This property is to decide the behaviour # when the input to the API contains attributes from both the indices. If the value is unset, the # behaviour is to process the index corresponding to the indexLookup element appearing first in the input XML definition. If the value is set to 'INTERSECTION', search will be performed against all the indices enabled for that API, and the intersection of the results will be used to determine the colonies to obtain data from. If api.colony.indexer is set to either disabled or nonindexed, this property is ignored. Allowed Values: 1. INTERSECTION 2. <blank> Default Value : INTERSECTION

Set this property to 'Y' to enable the 'Sterling Search Index' feature. This will index all entities that are enabled for indexing (e.g. Order, Shipment). Note that this MUST be enabled if 'api.colony.indexer' above is set to 'ssi' Allowed Values: Y, N Default Value: N

According to Sterling Search Index, the Entity Indexing is enabled in the entity configuration. The attributes to be indexed is also configured at the same place. The propagation of indexable content from Sterling transactions to the physical search index is handled in the backend framework and is unconditional except providing a facility to turn it off globaly by setting yfs.ssi.enabled=N. There are various 'indexing' entities enabled for for distinct purposes in Sterling OM. Setting the above property will enable them all. Customers are therefore requested to assess these purposes, identify the entities which are not required to index, disable them and avoid populating search index unnecessarily. The below property disables indexing for the entities. This is a comma separated list of XMLName of the entities on which indexing to be disabled.

This property holds the name of the search engine. Based on the name provided here, other properties will be looked up from below. If a custom implementation is being provided, specify a <custom value> here. Then uncomment properties corresponding to <custom value> below Allowed values: 1. elasticsearch 2. <custom value> Default value: elasticsearch

This property indicates the class name that provides the implementation of the search engine client. The property corresponding to search engine name 'xyz', would be 'yfs.ssi.search.engine.xyz.class'. Therefore, if <custom value> is chosen as the search.engine.name, provide the fully qualified class name under 'yfs.ssi.search.engine.<custom value>.class' property below. Uncomment and set the following to use with the <custom value> implementation:
The following enables the out of box elasticsearch implementation. Do not change.

This property determines the periodicity with which search index will be updated through a batch operation. The value provided here is the time in seconds after which another batch will be submitted to the search engine.

This property enables the 'fast fail' logic. The fast fail logic ensures that upon 'continuous failure', indexing into the search engine and searching from the search engine would be stopped temporarily until the problem is fixed. In case of continuous failure in either indexing or search operation, the corresponding operation is not attempted again until the user fixes the problem and re-enables the operation. Please refer to the documentation for more details on the API or SMA UI to be used to re-enable the operation. The index and search operations are tracked separately and the successes and failures on both the operations are sampled apart on each JVM (application or agent/integration servers) that does the said operation. The sampled events are used to determine if there has been a 'continuous failure'. Once a 'continuous failure' is determined by any one JVM the same is communicated to all the others, and the search/index operations are stopped on all the JVMs. The user is also notified of the same, so he can take corrective measures and re-enable index/search operations. The definition of what constitues a 'continuous failure' can be configured through a set of properties. Note that if the indexing operation continuously fails, the search operation is also automatically disabled. This is to avoid searching on an index which is now very likely dirty (since indexing operation has been continuously failing for some time).

The minimum duration of time (in mins) the index operation should fail to be treated as a 'continuous failure' situation. Indexing operation is said to continuously fail under the following conditions: a. If at least 50 (configurable) index operations were performed in a given JVM in the last 10 mins (configurable), and if there are at least 90% (configurable) of failures in that sample. b. If less than 50 index operations were performed in a given JVM in the last 10 mins, and among the last 50 samples, there is a 90% failure (irrespective of how long it took for 50 index operations to occur) E.g. If there is a load of 30 index operations per minute overall, and there are five application servers in the cluster to handle that load, each application server would be handling 60 such operations in 10 minutes. In such a case, the condition 'a' above will apply, and continuous failure will be determined based on 90% failure in this sample of 60 operations, viz. 54 failures out of 60. If, on the other hand, there were ten application servers handling the same load, there would have been only 30 such operations in 10 minutes. In that case, the condition 'b' is applied, and failure is determined only if there are 45 failures (90% of 50) in the last 50 index operations. This property is '10' in the example above and is one among the three configurable settings. Default Value: 10

The minimum sample count to be used to determine a 'continuous failure' situation. Indexing operation is said to continuously fail under the following conditions: a. If at least 50 (configurable) index operations were performed in a given JVM in the last 10 mins (configurable), and if there are at least 90% (configurable) of failures in that sample. b. If less than 50 index operations were performed in a given JVM in the last 10 mins, and among the last 50 samples, there is a 90% failure (irrespective of how long it took for 50 index operations to occur) E.g. If there is a load of 30 index operations per minute overall, and there are five application servers in the cluster to handle that load, each application server would be handling 60 such operations in 10 minutes. In such a case, the condition 'a' above will apply, and continuous failure will be determined based on 90% failure in this sample of 60 operations, viz. 54 failures out of 60. If, on the other hand, there were ten application servers handling the same load, there would have been only 30 such operations in 10 minutes. In that case, the condition 'b' is applied, and failure is determined only if there are 45 failures (90% of 50) in the last 50 index operations. This is '50' in the example above and is one among the three configurable settings. Default Value: 50

The failure threshold that, if crossed, indicates 'continuous failure'. Indexing operation is said to continuously fail under the following conditions: a. If at least 50 (configurable) index operations were performed in a given JVM in the last 10 mins (configurable), and if there are at least 90% (configurable) of failures in that sample. b. If less than 50 index operations were performed in a given JVM in the last 10 mins, and among the last 50 samples, there is a 90% failure (irrespective of how long it took for 50 index operations to occur) E.g. If there is a load of 30 index operations per minute overall, and there are five application servers in the cluster to handle that load, each application server would be handling 60 such operations in 10 minutes. In such a case, the condition 'a' above will apply, and continuous failure will be determined based on 90% failure in this sample of 60 operations, viz. 54 failures out of 60. If, on the other hand, there were ten application servers handling the same load, there would have been only 30 such operations in 10 minutes. In that case, the condition 'b' is applied, and failure is determined only if there are 45 failures (90% of 50) in the last 50 index operations. This is '90' in the example above and is one among the three configurable settings. Default Value: 90

Overrides for specific indexes The above yfs.ssi.fail.fast.. properties are globally applicable for all indexes. To override a property for a particular index, the property can be suffixed with '.<index-name>'. E.g. to override the 'yfs.ssi.fail.fast.index.monitor.time.mins' property for the index 'Order', the following property can be set: yfs.ssi.fail.fast.index.monitor.time.mins.Order=10 This can be done for all properties described above, and for all indexes available. Enable fail fast wrapper only for the following indexes. This is a comma separated list of indexes fail fast wrapper will be used for. For other indexes, the underlying search engine client will be used directly without the fail fast wrapper. Default: Order, Shipment
